Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story: I stared at my calendar, heart pounding. The design documents for our new feature were due tomorrow, and the other teams were waiting for my technical input. My manager had just sent a reminder: “Let’s finalize everything at the office function this afternoon. Everyone will be there—great chance to collaborate!” I knew how important it was to be present, to answer questions, to show I was a team player. But as I glanced at the invitation, I remembered the dress code: “Business casual—no jeans, please!” I felt a knot in my stomach. For me, dressing modestly isn’t just a preference; it’s a part of my faith. I always wore long sleeves and loose clothing, but I worried about standing out, about being judged or misunderstood by colleagues who didn’t know my reasons. I wanted to be seen as professional, not difficult or distant. The pressure to fit in, to be approachable, clashed with my need to stay true to my beliefs. As the clock ticked closer to the event, I felt torn, caught between my commitment to my team and my commitment to my faith, unsure how to move forward.
